Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing the Orbital Theory of Ice Ages Through Analysis of Glacial Deposits and Numerical Modeling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will examine the timing and causes of ice ages in the Southern Hemisphere and how these observed climate changes compare with those found in the Northern Hemisphere. A major question in the earth-system sciences has been ascertaining what drives different sections of Earth to switch in and out of ice age climates. This is an outstanding question that remains unresolved. The traditional Milankovitch or orbital "ice-age theory" proposes that the intensity of summer insolation received in the Northern Hemisphere paces ice ages across Earth. Measurements of the intensity of summer insolation in the Northern and Southern hemispheres have been found to be out of phase, however. If glaciers expand and retreat in similar ways around Earth at the same time, other driving mechanisms therefore must be involved, such as greenhouse gasses or a global impact of the largest ice sheets that covered the land in the Northern Hemisphere. A problem is that in the Southern Hemisphere, there is insufficient information regarding when the last cold glacial period started, how long it lasted, and when it ended. Without this information, scientists are ill-equipped to assess how well Southern Hemisphere glacial climates correspond to possible driving forces, such as changes in (orbital) solar insolation intensity, Northern Hemisphere ice sheets, and atmospheric carbon dioxide. They also are unable to assess the underlying causes of ice-age climates and to refine the Milankovitch theory. This project will focus on the collection and analyses of materials that help document how glaciers in southern South America have changed over time. The investigators will employ state-of-the-art techniques in dating glacier landforms and glacial-climate modeling. The dated paleogeography of glaciers will provide boundary conditions for experiments using models developed by the researchers and others to assess the roles and responses associated with possible climate parameters, such as temperature and precipitation ranges that are needed for an ice sheet to grow and retreat over the southern Andes.

This project will provide deeper understanding of the nature and causes of ice age climates and related natural environmental processes as well as their spatial and temporal differences around the globe. The project also will provide enhanced information about natural climate states, such as the climate during the last ice age that can be used as test beds for general circulation models that simulate future change. The project will provide opportunities to enhance international research collaborations between scientists in the U.S. and Chile. Education and training opportunities will be provided for undergraduate students, and educational outreach will be pursued through collaborative relationships with the American Museum of Natural History and New York City schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit and aim of our project focus around understanding better when southern South America and the Southern Hemisphere experienced cold Ice Age climates. We want to know when peak cold conditions occurred during the last Ice Age (also known as the Last Glacial Maximum), when they began and then when they ended and transitioned into the present interglacial warm period when civilizations developed. We also want to determine if the climate changes varied spatially around South America. The project fits within a larger goal of the Geoscience community to understand how and when different sections of Earth switch in and out of extreme Ice Age climates.

Solving this problem is important because the traditional Milankovitch (or orbital) theory posits that the intensity of summer insolation received (for example, how hot the summers get) in the Northern Hemisphere paces Ice Age climates across the entire Earth. The intensity of summer insolation in the Northern and Southern hemispheres is out-of-phase. Thus, if glaciers expand and retreat around Earth at different times, and do not simply follow Northern Hemisphere insolation intensity, then this provides a test of the Milankovitch Ice Age theory. Then, we need to evaluate or test other ideas for the main drivers of Ice Age climates in the Southern Hemisphere.

To this end, specific goals of this project included extensive field investigations in Patagonia to study deposits that represent former positions of ice sheets and glaciers during the last Ice Age. During the field work, the deposits were mapped in detail and boulder samples were collected that were left behind by former glaciers, for a technique known as cosmogenic surface exposure dating. With the primary dating techniques used, such analyses of the collected samples allow us to place the glacial deposits in a spatio-temporal framework of unprecedented precision.

There are several important outcomes or findings of the project, including at least the following. First, in a broad sense, we found the timing of each peak cold Ice Age climate, for at least the last ~300,000 years (three glacial cycles), does fit with Milankovitch orbital insolation changes, although there is not a direct or simple relation with summer insolation intensity in the Northern Hemisphere as originally posited. Second, the devil may be in the details; the precise start and end of a cold Ice Age period exhibit important differences between the Northern and Southern hemispheres, and perhaps show little direct linkage with Milankovitch orbital change, which is relatively gradual. For example, the end of the last Ice Age occurred earlier in the Southern Hemisphere, soon after 18,000 years ago, and was relatively rapid, with the Southern Andes losing most of its ice sheet within about 1,000-2000 years. This relatively rapid warming coincides with atmospheric CO2 rise, as documented (by others) in Antarctic ice cores, and occurred while North America and parts of northern Europe still laid buried under kilometers of ice that more slowly wasted away during this time. For comparison, the New York area and what is now the northeastern United States, appears to have remained gripped in cold Ice Age conditions for a few thousand years longer. Collaborating with the University of Maine is allowing us to use our new data and findings to constraint numerical modeling experiments, to reconstruct the ice sheet over Patagonia and quantify causal climate changes during the peak and end of the last Ice Age. Overall, the project's findings help improve understanding of the evolution of Southern Hemisphere climates over the last approximately 300,000 years.

In terms of broader impacts, one of the most important long-lasting outcomes was establishing a class that the PI now co-teaches with colleagues at the Universidad of Magallanes in Chile. This class has been taught almost every year since the project started (3 times), it has grown, and a field component now includes students from several countries. Hence, the project played a key role in building and strengthening international relations with Chilean colleagues, including students. The research was also the basis of Fulbright scholarships in Chile by both the PI Kaplan, and a graduate student that is integrated in the project. Moreover, we carried out numerous outreach and educational activities to the public over the award tenure, including leading a 1 day field trip for the Bronx County Historical Society and NYC Parks to teach people how to look for clues on the landscape to identify Ice Ages, and we worked with K-12 teachers in the NYC metropolitan area schools. In general, the project provided several researchers at different stages in their careers, including graduate students and undergraduate students, with new experience and expertise in several lines of research and mentoring.
